data.title: We Need to Start Seeing Powerful Men for What They Are
data.meta_description: Woody Allen’s ‘Manhattan’ is a creepy message from the past that explains our awful present. More autobiography than twisted fantasy, the film depicts a world that caters to male desire.
data.text:
I just finished watching Woody Allen’s celebrated 1979 romantic comedy Manhattan for the first time. (Growing up, I was always more of a Harold and Maude than an Annie Hall.) My initial reaction can be summed up by the popular, if overused, internet acronym “WTF,” which stands for “Why This Film?”

Why is this film a classic? Why is it beloved? Why do so many of my fancy movie nerd friends praise this bizarre, glib love letter to child abuse? Because it’s in black and white? Guess what: The original Godzilla is in black and white, and it’s a better film. It’s also not about a grown man sleeping with, and manipulating, a teen girl. The girl is played by Mariel Hemingway, who gives a heartbreaking and genuine performance that earned her an Oscar nomination, which I can only assume was an apology from a community that has long enabled powerful men.

‘Manhattan’ is a creepy message from the past that explains our awful present.

For those of you who aren’t familiar with Woody Allen movies, Manhattan is a cerebral comedy about a love triangle between a recently divorced middle-aged…
